fields.description:
A simple way to reproduce is to clone the project
https://github.com/boostorg/boost.git

and to switch to the develop branch. After a while, when updates come to the project, refreshing it becomes slower and slower. Often, in the logs view, changing the log line or refreshing the view hangs sourcetree.

A particularity of this project is to have many submodules and many files. 

Several crash logs attached.
fields.summary: When using the boost github project, sourcetree often hangs, is in general very slow, and crashes

fields.description: After temp_84 I checked out temp_85. Why SourceTree show different / wrong tree of commits compare to GitX what works well?! The bottom of the tree is also funny, there are two lines, not only one, one of the line has no ending. Sorry that I show not the full pic, I do not want to show commit texts. I often use cerry-pick and interactive rebase.
fields.summary: Strange tree of commits after check out.

fields.description: When you are in "Log Selected" popup window the shortcut to launch external diff tool (default: command+d) is disabled.
fields.summary: External Diff shortcut (Command+D) is disabled in "Log Selected" window

fields.description:
I have several maven projects where I am using the maven jgitflow plugin to manage the workflow. Although Sourcetree supports gitflow actions, this is currently of limited value to me, since it does not tie in with the maven nature of my project. The most obvious problem is that it does not update version numbers in poms when finishing releases. 

It would be great if we could somehow customize  Sourcetree to use the maven jgitflow commands.
fields.summary: Tie in gitflow support with maven project nature

fields.description: During "Add remote..." task, clicking the "hosted projects" (globe) button slides down a sheet which has the following two errors in its list of remote repositories: some repositories are listed twice and at least one, opengl-playpen on apokalypse_software's bitbucket account, is missing.
fields.summary: List of repos on hosted accounts is incorrect

fields.description:
On launch SourceTree is now crashing every time. I can't run the software. This seems to have happened after I added a new repo entry, but  I can't be sure.

I've restarted, deleted SourceTree and installed a new fresh copy, still same issue.

The Crash Reporter log file is attached to this ticket.

---------

Crashed Thread:  0  Dispatch queue: com.apple.main-thread

Exception Type:  EXC_BAD_ACCESS (SIGSEGV)
Exception Codes: KERN_INVALID_ADDRESS at 0x00000000bbadbeef
fields.summary: SourceTree Crashing on Launch

fields.description:
Summary:
If I'm in the "Current Branch" view of commit history, and I double-click on an old commit to detach the head, the head is detached appropriately but I get an error view with title "Error encountered" and message "'git log' failed with error code 128:'fatal: bad revision '(detached from 143338b)''". This pops up twice, and then the commit history view is blank. If I switch to "All Branches" view, I see commit history again.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. In the left-hand nav, click on the currently-checked out branch.
2. Make sure the View segmented control at top left is set to Log (the middle one).
3. In the branch filter drop-down, select "Current Branch."
4. Choose a previous revision in the commit list, and double-click on it to detach the working copy head.
5. Click OK on the warning that pops up.

Expected Results:
No error comes up. The branch filter is automatically switched to "All Branches" since the "Current Branch" filter is no longer applicable (I believe). Perhaps there's an alert telling the user about this (or some text could be added to the warning in step 5 above).

Actual Results:
An error pops up with the title/message listed in Summary above, and then the Current Branch filter remains in place. The list of commits is blank.
fields.summary: Detaching head while in Current Branch view results in error

fields.description:
When using a git repository and specifying a custom port via

ssh://${url}:${port}/${repo}.git

SourceTree fails to deliver an error message / warning message.

Observed:
- Gives no error message
- Does not update when switching between remote / local view
- Crashes after a few minutes

Expected:
- Give Warning on malformed url or failed connection attempt

Hoped for:
- Use custom port as specified
fields.summary: Crash when using ssh://${url}:${port}/${repo}.git url scheme

fields.description: Title says it all.
fields.summary: Allow applying individual hunks from a stash rather than the full stash

fields.description: For bitbucket repositories, It would be nice if we could get linked directly to the bitbucket page for a certain commit, so that we can do code review comments.
fields.summary: direct link to code commenting

fields.description:
This refers to the Bookmarks window, and the Add Repository pop up.

If I forget that I am NOT cloning a repository, but actually just adding an existing working copy, I will frequently begin to fill out the fields on the Clone Repository tab. Then I will remember that I'm on the wrong tab, and I will switch to the Add Working Copy tab.

On the Add Working Copy tab, the Path will be empty, even though I just filled out the desired data on the Clone Repository tab.

I propose that these fields be linked, or the equivalent, so that switching between the tabs does not require users to copy or otherwise re-browse for the desired path twice.
fields.summary: link Clone Repository URL field and Add Working Copy Path field for Add Repository Bookmark

fields.description: The selected stash tooltip has bold font and a shadow which is hard to read on yellow background.
fields.summary: Improve Selected Stash Tooltip

fields.description: Just like the picture attached, my log messages(in Chinese) are shown as a mess in the upper window, but in the bottom window every log message is shown correctly. Most of these commits are made through SourceTree 1.8.1, the others are done in a terminal with UTF-8 encoding.
fields.summary: Log messages are shown as a mess

fields.description:
I would like the editor for commit messages to show the character count for the line I am typing.

Where I work we follow the 50/70 rule for our commit messages. The first line should not exceed 50 characters, all other lines shouldn't exceed 70 characters. Since the commit message editor doesn't show how long my line is I need to resort to writing my commit messages in another editor and then paste it in SourceTree.

It would really speed up my workflow if SourceTree would show the character count for the line in the commit message editor.
fields.summary: Show the character line count in the commit editor

fields.description:
I have a custom action that could and files to Sublime Text

Script to Run:
bq. /Applications/Sublime Text 2.app/Contents/SharedS

Parameters:
bq. -a $FILE

with the shortcut being Alt-Shift-S

Now this just changes the focus for _some_ files but still opens other files (both files definitely still exist in the same path)
fields.summary: Custom "Launch File in Sublime Text" Action no longer working

fields.description:
Currently, Sourcetree offers support for GitHub, such as looking up repositories and creating pull requests.  However, the URL for GitHub is set to 'https://www.github.com' and cannot be changed.

If possible, those features that use GitHub should also work with GitHub Enterprise, which is an internally hosted version of the same platform.  It would be nice to be able to change the GitHub URL to point to a company's internal GitHub Enterprise server rather than just the public one.
fields.summary: Add support for GitHub Enterprise

fields.description:
This problem has persisted for a while now. I utilize Github's Two Factor Authentication for my account and Sourcetree routinely forgets the password and I have to re-generate a token and re-enter it into Sourcetree when I attempt to push up to a branch.

As far as reproducing it, usually after a few pushes up to the branch Sourcetree will prompt me for the password which then requires me to go and generate a new one over at Github.com. It happens at least 2-3 times a day.
fields.summary: Sourcetree forgets Github Personal Access Tokens required by two factor authentication

fields.description: Along with the filtering I filed as a separate ticket, it would be nice to be able to sort the branch list in various ways, such as most recent commit. I use a small bash alias to generate a list sorted by most recent commit, and it's very useful for finding recent branches.
fields.summary: Sort branches by most recent commit

fields.description:
The internal diff view can get blurry on certain files when scrolling. I've noticed it on Xcode project files (project.pbxproj). I've included a screen shot. I've only noticed this issue on my external monitor. 

"Backgrounding" the app and coming back to it doesn't seem to help. Moving the SourceTree window to the retina display does clear this issue up. 

I have not noticed this on my retina display.
fields.summary: Internal diff view get blurry when scrolling
improved tag ordering

fields.description: I'm working in a codebase with a very very long list of branches, and it would be nice if the list on the left side of the application had a filter text field to locate things quickly (local and remote branches)
fields.summary: Filter text field for branches

fields.description:
When I scroll the hunk diff pane (showing the diff of the hunk selected in the current commit pane), the pane redraws badly. The artifacts are bad enough that the pane becomes completely unreadable and useless.

See attached screenshot.

When I dragged the SourceTree window onto my laptop screen and scrolled the diff pane, I didn't see any artifacts--it worked correctly.
fields.summary: Scrolling the hunk diff pane generates lots of bad artifacts

fields.description:
Feature:

Add an "Open in Finder" button to each SourceTree project's toolbar. (see picture)

This opens the project's root directory in the finder.

This would offer the same feature and convenience as the current "Terminal" button. But it opens in Finder instead, for GUI operations.

Workflow:

Often I want to edit a file in the project I am viewing via SourceTree.

To do this, I laboriously navigate to the enclosing Finder folder and open the file.

It would be better for SourceTree to surface a quick shortcut to the root of the project's directory (the location of the .git file).

This would be a very convenient shortcut to quickly begin editing the files you are currently viewing via SourceTree.
fields.summary: Add "Open in Finder" button to toolbar

fields.description:
Command-tabbing back to the SourceTree window, the app froze. I had to force-quit it. Attached is the stack trace.

At the time I had a single Git repository window open, and also the Bookmarks window behind it.
fields.summary: SourceTree freezes when command-tabbing back to window

fields.description:
In the commit dialog the staged files window is corrupted when scrolling.

Steps to reproduce:
- stage some files from your working tree to index
- right-click on the staged file(s) and select 'commit' from the context menu
- in the commit dialog, do a two finger scroll downward in the 'File staged in the index' window
- note that the view will be corrupted

Note:
This happens in my SourceTree, but when I try to reproduce it on my colleagues MacBook it won't show. He however said that he has seen the same behaviour but for him it was in the commit dialog's Diff View. I suppose it might be related the size of the window, or the commit dialog?
fields.summary: In commit window the 'Files staged in the index' view is being corrupted when you scroll
Support Beyond Compare 4 for MacOSX

fields.description:
I'm using HgFlow and my currently active branch is usually DEVELOP. If I use HgFlow to start a new Release, then when I finish that release, SourceTree always switches back to the DEFAULT branch instead of the previously current branch (ie. DEVELOP in this case). This means that to continue work, I have to manually switch back to the DEVELOP branch, which is error-prone (ie. a couple of times I have forgotten to switch back and then committed changes to the DEFAULT branch instead of the DEVELOP branch).

When finishing/closing a RELEASE branch, can you switch back to the previously active branch, instead of always switching back to the DEFAULT branch.

My scenario is usually simple in that I'm on DEVELOP, then to do a release, start a new RELEASE branch, change the version strings, commit and then finish the RELEAE branch (ie. so the previously active branch is always DEVELOP).

However, as some people may start a release branch, switch to a different branch(es) in between (could be anything), then finish the feature release, the ideal solution would be to keep track of the previously active branch when switching to a new branch, so you can go back to it when finishing.closing a branch.
fields.summary: HgFlow: Finishing a Release always switches back to default branch instead of previously used branch

fields.description:
When you go to clone an existing repo and you have a GitHub account added, all repo's you have "starred" on GitHub will show-up as well as your own repos.

Turns a small selective list into quite a large list. (In my case)

A sort filter or option to display or not display starred repos would be awesome.
fields.summary: Filter starred GitHub repos to set apart from real repos.

fields.description: If diff isn't displayed in diff view (diff suppressed), then External Diff button in the diff view is disabled, although external diff can be opened either via context menu or main menu (or with Cmd-D shortcut).
fields.summary: external diff button is disabled in diff view

fields.description:
SourceTree hangs on OSX on a regular basis while on the main window (the repository list). It happens randomly but rather often, typically a few times a week and it's been happening since... well, since I started using it quite a while ago. I keep sending those reports using the system ForceQuit crash reporter but I'm not sure you're actually getting them from Apple :)

I don't know how to reproduce the issue as it seems to be random but if there's anything else I can do to help diagnose the bug please let me know.

System crash log attached.
fields.summary: SourceTree hangs on OSX on a regular basis

fields.description:
Right click on any merge commit and choose 'Reverse commit...'->OK

The error message is
{quote}git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c credential.helper=sourcetree revert --no-edit 8137de37b91c056d605484aee0c59d93b7a8cdf7 
error: Commit 8137de37b91c056d605484aee0c59d93b7a8cdf7 is a merge but no -m option was given.
fatal: revert failed
Completed with errors, see above{quote}

if the command also had the option {code}-m 1{code} then it would work, however it would of course be better to set m to the correct number of commits that comprise the length of the branch, or get the user to select a valid commit and set m accordingly
fields.summary: Reverse Commit fails on merge commits

fields.description:
I have a number of remote git repositories setup for the folks I work with. Many contain branches that I'm not interested in - they do however get displayed in the main window.

I'd like to be able to select the set of remote repos that get displayed in the main window. 

I'd also like to select the branches from local/remote repos that get displayed in the main window.

This is especially important when there are many merge commits.
fields.summary: Allow show/hide of selected remote repositories/branches

fields.description:
You gave us a great feature - subtrees. But it is critical needs work. As a minimum, the following things that will make this opportunity a truly magnificent:
1) to display the status of the source subtree - whether there are changes in it , that you can PULL to yourself.
2) similarly display local state subtree relative to the source - is there a change that can be PUSHED into the subtree's source
3) an optional possibility to PUSH/PULL the source along with the general PUSH/PULL of the repository
4) AND - remember the password in the keychain for the subtree's source! it is impossible to enter it each time (and I have not one but many subtrees)
fields.summary: Subtrees push/pull

fields.description: Most applications remember their positions when you reboot your Mac when using multiple monitors. SourceTree is one that doesn't appear to. Everytime I reboot the windows reappear in a random monitor (I have 3 monitors)
fields.summary: SourceTree doesn't remember position in multi monitor setup

fields.description: Is it possible to enable "Sign commit" by default if "Enable GPG key signing for commits" is enabled?
fields.summary: Enable "Sign commit" by default if "Enable GPG key signing for commits" is enabled

fields.description: If I move a local repository to a different location on the same disk, the bookmarks window shows "Repository moved or deleted".  If SourceTree's bookmarks were actually implemented using what Apple calls a "bookmark", or the older alias data, then it would know where the folder moved to and wouldn't have to scold me.
fields.summary: Bookmark should auto-update when local repository is moved

fields.description: When I try to push to a remote repo, the application seems to only look at the first line of .netrc.  I have to rearrange the order of my accounts in .netrc depending on which repo I want to push to.
fields.summary: application only looks at first line of .netrc file

fields.description:
It would be nice if there were a preference to enable manual refresh of remote status on the bookmarks.  If this preference were turned on, then there could then be a refresh icon available on each bookmark, plus perhaps a refresh icon on folders (refreshes all bookmarks in that folder) plus a refresh icon in the toolbar of the bookmarks window (fires off a refresh of all visible bookmarks, just like the default action that occurs now every time the bookmarks are opened).

To really do things nicely, there could also be some sort of indicator displayed on each bookmark showing how many minutes/hours/days it has been since that bookmark was last refreshed.

This could really improve my perception of the program, as one of the biggest drags for me right now is checking my folders to try and find a particular bookmark and having everything lock up while the bookmarks in the folder all refresh from remotes.  Worse still is if I try to use the search field on the bookmarks, as that then triggers an automatic refresh on all of the bookmarks regardless of if they are inside a collapsed folder.
fields.summary: Bookmarks manual refresh

fields.description:
Currently, SourceTree use a fake user.email <username>@<computername> if it is not set.

It will be better if SourceTree will prompt for user info if it is not set.
fields.summary: prompt for user info if not existing

fields.description:
STEPS:
# Commit changes to local repo
# Observe that a new "icon" overlay appears on top of the "Push" icon in the top action menu. This red icon overlay shows a count of the changesets which have not yet been pushed to the remote repo (common Mac paradigm). Please refer to the attached screenshot.
# Now click somewhere in the branch graph (e.g. select some node besides the top, default node) or elsewhere in the SourcTree app

RESULT:
The red icon is cleared/removed, even though the changesets have not yet been pushed to the remote repo.

EXPECTED RESULT:
Only clear/reset this icon after push action is complete. This is a powerful and helpful reminder of the state of your local repo.
fields.summary: icon showing count of pending change-sets to be pushed is cleared / removed too quickly

fields.description:
In the attached repository, where two branches both change a single file. Attempt to merge and elect to keep the changes from my branch/"Keep mine"/Discard. The merge commit will disappear from the commit history. Pressing commit in SourceTree still shows the appropriate commit message, but there is no indication that a commit is needed.

$ git status
# On branch B
# All conflicts fixed but you are still merging.
#   (use "git commit" to conclude merge)
#
nothing to commit, working directory clean
fields.summary: Merge commits that contain no changes do not show up as uncommitted.

fields.description:
# Steps to reproduce

1. Open a existing Git repository in Sourcetree
2. Click the top right gear icon to open the Settings dialogue window
3. Click Edit Config File…

_The repository specific config file opens in Text Editor_

4. Add a new remote to the config file, for example:

[remote "prod"]
	url = ssh://deploy@xxxxx.co.uk/srv/_git/xxxxxxxxxxx.com.git
	fetch = +refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/prod/*

5. Save the config file

# Result

At some point after saving the config file and before the interface refreshes, other configuration instructions such as branches are deleted from the config file

Adding new remotes using the GUI works fine.
fields.summary: Adding a new remote repository using "Edit Config File…" removes/reorders the config file content on save

fields.description:
I'm using the SourceTree app on a work computer (not personal) so I don't want to save my BitBucket password in the local Mac keychain. Instead, I would prefer to enter the password per operation or once per SourceTree launch. (I use this approach on my Windows machine using TortoiseHg and it works quite nicely.)

If I choose not to save my password in the local keychain (unselect  "Store Password In Keychain" checkbox in various dialogs), then whenever I am prompted for my BitBucket password I must enter it (correctly) 4 times.  Each time I enter the correct password, the dialog closes then immediately reappears.

This problem is 100% repeatable and I'm certain that I am entering the password correctly each time.

I imagine my situation is not that uncommon (don't want to save in keychain), and this seems like quite an inconvenience to me.
fields.summary: always prompted for BitBucket password 4x if I choose not to save in Mac keychain

fields.description:
I quite often make the mistake of committing to a detached head in a submodule, necessitating a quick bit of cleanup.

Ideally, I'd like the option to turn on a warning when this happens. The warning would say something like "You're committing to a detached head, is that what you really wanted to do?". Ideally the dialog would also give you the option to commit to a branch instead - offering you a list of branches who's position match the current head.

This would fix the single biggest annoyance I have with my git / submodules / SourceTree workflow.
fields.summary: Option to warn before committing to a detached head

fields.description:
When I (accidentally) committed a change with the following description, my commit was lost in the sense that it is not shown in GUI. When I try to rebase children of the topmost visible commit, I can see the lost one, which means it's correctly stored in Git repo, but not shown properly in SourceTree. The description is:
commit: <U+200C>Blog optimization

base on "git reflog" command.
fields.summary: commit containing unicode title is lost!

fields.description:
The field should strip out any CR/LF characters (or perhaps replace them with spaces or dashes). e.g. copy the following into the create or rename branch field:

3871
feature

Depending on how the copied text was selected by the user, it might show just the "feature" or might appear as though nothing was copied until the user thinks to press the up arrow. It if became "3871-feature", a fully visible and valid branch name, that would be nice.
fields.summary: Copying multi-line text into create / rename branch field

fields.description:
When I'm on a detached head state in git, SourceTree pops up an error message (sometimes multiple times in a row) that I have to click away. This is incredibly frustrating and unwelcome to my workflow, where I'm frequently on a detached head as a result of some automated tools we use for git branch management.

Please provide a preference to have this alert dialog not appear, or show it in some less-intrusive way in the UI.
fields.summary: Popup alert dialog when on detached head is incredibly frustrating

fields.description: Currently there is no way to add a file I wish to ignore to $GIT_DIR/info/exclude, only .git_ignore and the global config. This would allow me to ignore files that get created by tools on my system, but that I don't want to add to one repo's git ignore, although sometimes to another repo.
fields.summary: Allow ignoring a file for just the local repo for git

fields.description:
As a user, when I right-click on a file to use its context menu to find the function to show a file's commit history, I am expecting to see something like, "Show commit history" or "Show history" or "Show history of changes" or ..     Currently, this sought action is labeled "Log History" and is confusing to me.

Rationale:
The current label, "Log History" sounds like a directive to execute against the selected file.  As a user, I don't want to poke around experimenting and potentially messing up files.  As a Bronius, it took a googling to identify this function as what I'd been looking for before I located this menu item and tried it.  I now know where it is and use it regularly, but this kind of leap of faith or learning curve would not be needed if it were more clear.  Also, the "selected" may not be necessary: It is common UX that if an item is selected and a context menu is shown, the context of action is the selected item.

Love SourceTree-- excellent app!!!
fields.summary: Change file context menu item label "Log Selected" to something more intuitive

fields.description:
It appears that sourcetree checks all of its bookmarked repositories when pushing a commit to a remote repository. Because of this eager polling of the bookmarks our security team is having a hard time distinguishing our sourcetree traffic from bruit force scanners because of the high volume of connections it tries to make in a short time period.  The security team sees a our developers commit/push from sourcetree as 3+(Number of Bookmarks) connection attempts within a few seconds, which does seem suspicious to them. 

Our work around is to not have more than 10 bookmarks in source tree, but that seems rather limiting. An idea to prevent false positive security threats on the network would be to spread out the background polling of bookmarked repos so that they don't all run at the same time, possibly offset by a random value between 10 to 60 seconds.  A default threshold for brute force attacks on several security scanners is 20 connections in a 60 second interval. Even a configuration option to adjust the aggressiveness of the polling would be nice. 

In an office setting, these kinds of security systems are common and I think the default setting should not make source tree appear as a security threat just because of the number of bookmarks a user has.
fields.summary: Smarter polling for bookmarked repositories

fields.description:
It would be good if 'discard' operations where undoable.

I was just preparing some files to commit, and accidentally hit the 'discard' button when I meant to hit 'discard hunk', and appear to have now permanently lost my changes (well, until I go delving through time machine).

Apparently I'm not the first person to do this:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11418429/how-to-undo-discard-if-not-committed

If it's not possible/easy to undo, leaving a copy of the file somewhere it could be recovered from manually would be useful (unless that already happens and I just don't know where to look!).
fields.summary: Allow discarding file to be undone

fields.description:
See attached screenshot.

Every time I load the graph / tree view, SourceTree reverts my selection of "Current Branch" to "All Branches" on the graph view toolbar. It also doesn't remember my "Show Remote Branches" deactivation.

This is an issue as we have a very large repo with several hundred remote branches and tags. The graph view can load quite slow, and really all I need to see is what's local.

fields.description: I wish there was a preference that would allow one to set the default flag to be used for  things like spelling auto-correct, and etc. in the commit message field.  There have been so many times that I've committed a change with some domain specific term that has been auto-corrected to an English word that it is starting to be annoying.  For example, docset is corrected to docket, venv to vent, etc.  I realize that this is a builtin feature of the native text widget, but it does have the ability to turn them on or off.
fields.summary: Preference to turn off auto-correct

fields.description: Since there is an entirely separate option to show untracked, those files should not show up in the show pending view.

fields.description:

This might also be relevant for Stashes in git...
fields.summary: Double clicking shelved work should unshelve

fields.description:
In the File Status View, the pop-up menu has an "Expand All" option, but this is a one-time action.  It should be sticky.

When a file deep in a subdirectory tree is modified, only the top directory gets added to the list.  You have to go through multiple steps to show what file(s) were modified, either by clicking on each directory in the path to the modified files, or by selecting Expand All again.  If Expand All were sticky I would always see all modified files.

The best behavior would be to remember Expand All as the default for new directories which appear in the list.  Directories I've minimized should stay minimized until I Expand All explicitly again.
fields.summary: Expand All should be sticky

fields.description:

Or possibly just remember the last path a repo was previously cloned to.

fields.description:
In the HTTP proxy settings, allow URL/domain pattern exclusions to be specified. 

Right now I have repositories that I access externally (at BitBucket) where I have to go through a proxy and then I have repositories internally (in Stash) that I cannot use the proxy that I need to access at the same time

It would be nice to be able to put in a domain exclusion, like *.example.com should not use the proxy.

fields.description: Since there's an checkbox to sign commits using GPG it would be nice to have an option somewhere in the settings that lets an user enable this checkbox by default.

Using SourceTree 1.8.0.3

Right click branch -> Create pull request... 

Nothing happens. Would like an error message at least

Connected to Stash
fields.summary: Create pull request does not work and no error message

fields.description:
When working on a project with multiple branches/tags it's hard to tell in which branches/tags this particular commit is contained.

EGit (for Eclipse) and GitExtensions provide such information (see attached screenshots)

It would be really handy to have such feature in SourceTree
fields.summary: Display containing branches/tags for the commit

fields.description:
I'm really happy with SourceTree, but one limitation that affects me almost daily is the lack of granularity in the integrated diff viewer. If I add a single comma to a long, one-line SQL statement, the diff viewer marks the entire line as having been replaced. I have to meticulously scan the added/removed lines looking for the one actual difference.

I understand that this was considered "not possible" back in April '13 (https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/161107/word-by-word-diff-for-sourcetree#161525), but I hope that a solution will be found. Bitbucket and GitHub highlight line differences. And FileMerge, Xcode, and Bazaar Explorer go even further and display helpful visual "bridges" between modifications. SourceTree's diff viewer seems pretty creaky in comparison.
fields.summary: Highlight line differences in integrated diff viewer

fields.description: When merging branches with SourceTree, we get a confirmation prompt similar to "Are you sure you want to merge 'some branch name' into your current branch?".  It would help a lot if the current branch were named explicitly, as it is, we often cancel the operation to double check what the current branch is (the two branches frequently are not visible at the same time).  Naming the current branch in the confirmation would let us do this double check using the confirmation dialog.
fields.summary: Use the current branch name instead of "current branch" in prompts

fields.description:
Summary:
Attempt to checkout remote branch which has corresponding local branch now end up in an error which says that branch already exists. It may also suggest to checkout local branch and pull that local branch then.

Detailed description:
Let's say we have a `develop` local branch and `origin/develop` that is ahead of `develop` by 2 commits. Local branch `develop` tracks `origin/develop`.
Consider the following scenario: 

step 1) When you double-click on a latest commit on `origin/develop` default action is performed: SrcTree tries to checkout the branch. Running that action ends up in an error that informs of local branch `develop` that already exist. Now there's no way to go forward in that case. 

In my opinion that's not the most common thing users want to do if remote branch is tracked. In my case that would be just to checkout local branch and have it up-to-date.

step 2) The only thing possible after "step1" is to (a) dismiss the error pop-up, (b) checkout local `develop` branch manually, (c) pull this branch. Then it's up to date with `remote/develop`.

What I'd like to see is for SrcTree to suggest me to perform "step 2" automatically (for example by adding a button to the error message shown in "step 1") if it detects there's a local branch that tracks remote branch `origin/develop`.
At least sub-steps 2a and 2b should be automated and pull dialog should be shown for me to choose if I want to rebase for example.
fields.summary: Suggest pulling on checkout when remote branch is tracked by local

fields.description:
Reported here: http://blog.sourcetreeapp.com/2013/12/11/sourcetree-for-mac-1-8-subtree-support-mavericks-improvements/#comment-1221106811

Issue described here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19712735/git-svn-cannot-setup-tracking-information-starting-point-is-not-a-branch

Critical as you can't checkout branches for tracking in git-svn
fields.summary: git-svn checkout branch bug

fields.description:
SourceTree is stalling or crashing more often than I'd like it to.
For you to fix these bugs wouldn't it help if you'd have the crash reports?

You should include a crash reporter framework in SourceTree for Mac to automatically have these crash reports sent to you.
fields.summary: Add a crash reporter to SourceTree

fields.description:
I have a bundle directory in my project. When I modify the contents of a file inside it, SourceTree does not show any 'uncommited changes'.
This is the output of git status when I do that :

# HEAD detached at 68c488e
# Changes not staged for commit:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
#   (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
#
#	modified:   JTLocalization.bundle/ru.lproj/Localizable.strings
#
no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")

But sourcetree shows nothing.
fields.summary: Sourcetree does not recognize changed files in bundles

fields.description:
When adding Stash as a hosted server it would be nice to be able to select SSH as the default protocol.

This should be possible when Stash 2.11 is released:

https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-3160
fields.summary: Supported SSH as preferred protocol for Stash Hosted Projects

fields.description:
In OS X 10.9.1 Mavericks, the System Preferences > Keyboard > Text > "Use smart quotes and dashes" global setting is controlling smart quotes and dashes in the SourceTree commit message textfield.

"Use smart quotes and dashes" is enabled by default in OS X, and thus SourceTree is using smart quotes by default.

I would argue that that "Use smart quotes and dashes" should never be enabled in the commit message textfield. It could be turned on manually on a  per-commit basis, if desired. 

SourceTree should ignore the global setting for Smart Quotes and Smart Dashes.
fields.summary: Commit messages should not use Smart Quotes and Smart Dashes by default.

fields.description:
OS X Mavericks has a global "Correct spelling automatically" setting under System Preferences > Keyboard > Text

I have this option unchecked. However, SourceTree's Commit Message textfield continues to automatically correct my spelling (even after restarting the app).

Red lines under misspelled words are great. However, I do not want the blue lines and iOS-like automatic spelling correction.

Other apps respect this global setting. If you change the global setting and then restart the app, the new spelling correction mode will take effect. This does not occur in SourceTree.

I am aware that the spelling correction can be turned off for SourceTree individually. But that's not a fix for this issue of not respecting the global defaults.

 > In Lion this is no longer a system-wide option. Right-click on the commit text area, select Spelling and Grammar, and alter the Check / Correct options as appropriate. SourceTree 1.4 onwards remembers these settings and they're remembered independently of any other application.

https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/58370/how-to-disable-spelling-correction-in-sourcetree-commit-messages

If it was missing from Lion, the global setting is definitely back in 10.9 Mavericks. SourceTree should use it.
fields.summary: SourceTree should respect OS X's global "Correct spelling automatically" setting.

fields.description:
I happened to have the Console.app running when I launched SourceTree 1.8.0.3. When I did, I saw some messages logged that might be worth looking into. Not sure if they are truly problems or not, but thought it worth mentioning.

These happened upon just launching SourceTree, which did auto-open the Bookmarks window.

-----

1/26/14 7:21:09.237 AM SourceTree[1941]: SourceTree(1941,0x104ef6000) malloc: *** auto malloc[1941]: error: GC operation on unregistered thread. Thread registered implicitly. Break on auto_zone_thread_registration_error() to debug.

1/26/14 7:21:09.360 AM SourceTree[1941]: registerCustomValueTransformers on main thread

(that one probably isn't a problem, but I wanted to provide it as it may give some hint as to the timing of the other console messages).

1/26/14 7:21:09.535 AM SourceTree[1941]: CoreData: Error: Unable to dynamically link Librarian.framework
1/26/14 7:21:12.744 AM SourceTree[1941]: BUG in libdispatch client: kevent[EVFILT_WRITE] delete: "No such file or directory" - 0x2


I think the main curiousity is the GC operation.
fields.summary: Possible problematic console messages

fields.description:
SourceTree hangs periodically for me. Sometimes when pushing to remote. Sometimes when committing local. Sometimes when staging files for commit. Once it even hung when I was clicking on a file to see a diff. It is an indefinite hang and requires a force-quit.

Others have reported that it is when they come back to the app.  That isn't always the case for me.  It sometimes will work for a minute or so, just long enough for me to be committing or pushing.
fields.summary: Periodically hangs and I have to force quit.

fields.description:
After committing some code, I often want to send the commit to someone in the form of the URL of the commit on the web. Github, especially, has a great web view of each commit.

Example of such a URL:  
https://github.com/pkamb/PowerKey/commit/95895af3bcd04ade0c8a9479bda1cff96a4e67e5

My workflow, currently, is to navigate to Github.com, find the repository, find the branch, find the commit, and copy the URL.

If the commit was some time in the past, it is very annoying to find the commit. I need to first click through several pages in the history.


Feature:  
SourceTree should generate a link to the commit on Github and/or Bitbucket.

Display this URL:
 - Right-click menu of each commit
 - Commit detail view (see picture)

Right-click menu item could change depending on the repository type:
 - "Open on Github"
 - "Open on Bitbucket"
 - etc.

Also would be very convenient to have a "copy link" rather than "open link" action.
 - Copy SHA-1 to Clipboard
 - Copy Web Link to Clipboard
fields.summary: Generate Github/Bitbucket URL for each commit; show in right-click menu and detail view.

fields.description:
On commits that involve multiple files, only the first file is shown in the log viewer.

However, this commit modified 7 files, even though only one is shown by SourceTree.
git show --pretty="format:" --name-only d504f5f7cf3e562fc1f07330ab49a43116ef5f7f

Project/Common/AOSLogger.m
Project/Daemon/AOSConfigurationManager.h
Project/Daemon/Accounts/AOSAccountStoreFMF.m
Project/Daemon/Accounts/AOSAppleAccountManager.h
Project/Daemon/Accounts/AOSAppleAccountManager.m
Project/Daemon/Providers/AOSFMFServiceProvider.m
Project/Daemon/Transports/AOSNotifyAuthMessage.m

I think this is a recent regression in 1.8.0.3 since I used to never have this issue until the latest update.
fields.summary: File list in commit view can be totally hidden (shouldn't be able to do this)

fields.description:
Sometimes when merging a feature branch (with/without git flow), it's a bit tedious when the target branch is not up to date. In this case the target branch needs to be checked out and pulled before the merge.

This is not necessary and easily avoided using the console:
http://stackoverflow.com/a/17722977/354018
{code}
git fetch <remote> <remote branch>:<local branch>
{code}

It's safe as it just allows fast-forwards.

*Feature Request:* Add this as an option to the context menu for local tracking branches.
fields.summary: Fast-Forward Non-Checked-Out Branches

fields.description:
When trying to filter the log view by selecting one of the local branches in the branch filter popup (leftmost), the filtering is always done using master, not the selected branch.

This error has been in SourceTree For Mac for some time now, it's not a recent regression.
fields.summary: Log view's branch filter popup doesn't work properly

fields.description: It may be worth adding functionality to SourceTree that stops trying automatic fetches if a certain number has failed, rather than continuing to make them until it causes accounts to be locked.
fields.summary: Cancel Automatic Fetches After Failures

fields.description:
Button labels between OSX and Windows versions of SourceTree are very inconsistent. For example the clear "Discard" in Windows is called "Reset" in OSX. Likewise Stash is called Shelve in OSX.

Please unify these. At the moment I think the Windows texts are better because they relate to VCS functionality much better.
fields.summary: Inconsistent button labels between Windows and Mac versions

fields.description:
Request a facility for allowing periodic Fetch. In an asynchronous environment without tight workflow agreements, it is sometimes helpful to have awareness of what is changing in remotes. 
Perhaps a simple "fetch all remotes" with a time interval? 
One could also imagine "jobs" where only certain repos are Fetched. 
I would think a Pull would still be manual in nature as it could be destructive or require merging. 
Thank you,
David
fields.summary: Request a setting to periodically Fetch automatically (refresh status of remotes)

fields.description:
I have had two files starting with " --> ", called "-->.html" and "-->.hlp". Both were not in the index.

Sourcetree parsed these names wrongly as ".html" and ".hlp", which lead to the following error when trying to add them to the index.

"Git: cannot checkout branch - error: pathspec '.html' did not match any file(s) known to git"

and the analog for the .hlp file.

Adding them via command line git removed any errors.
fields.summary: Files starting with "-->" not properly parsed, unable to add to index

fields.description: Uganda isn't listed as a country in the registration process
fields.summary: Uganda not listed on list of countries during registration

fields.description:
When SourceTree is running for a few days without being turned off, the number of descriptors of opened files becomes too large and eventually the system runs off file descriptors. Most of them are pipes, example output of lsof command is given below.
{code}iMac-Evgenia:scripts fedor$ lsof | grep "SourceTre" | wc -l
    3932
iMac-Evgenia:scripts fedor$ lsof
COMMAND     PID  USER   FD     TYPE             DEVICE   SIZE/OFF        NODE NAME
...
SourceTre  3021 fedor 3574     PIPE 0xffffff801afcdd30       4096     
SourceTre  3021 fedor 3575     PIPE 0xffffff801b0591b0       4096   
SourceTre  3021 fedor 3576     PIPE 0xffffff8035715d60       4096 
SourceTre  3021 fedor 3577     PIPE 0xffffff8029292310       4096 
SourceTre  3021 fedor 3578     PIPE 0xffffff8025641c80       4096

SourceTre  3021 fedor 3580     PIPE 0xffffff80271e0000       4096
SourceTre  3021 fedor 3581     PIPE 0xffffff801d400a70       4096

After SourceTree is restarted, the number of file descriptors becomes normal. But as the time goes on, their number increases. The following commands are executed with the interval of about 1 - 5 minutes. It looks like some leakage of descriptors.

fields.description:
To reproduce:

- clone a git repo
- branch master to foo
- checkout master
- commit something
- checkout foo
- select the commit that is NOT in foo
- right-click, rebase children of <SHA> interactively...
- ERROR: nothing happens.
- check console.app (system log)
- see something like:

{noformat}
1/17/14 2:12:41.382 PM SourceTree[2168]: SourceTree(2168,0x10502e000) malloc: *** auto malloc[2168]: error: GC operation on unregistered thread. Thread registered implicitly. Break on auto_zone_thread_registration_error() to debug.

fields.summary: SourceTree application becomes unresponsive

fields.description: In Mercurial we use bundling to merge in the set of pre-fetched changes to half the amount of bandwidth used. The problem with this is that automatic merge messages use the bundle path rather than what was merged in. Need a workaround to have merge messages as they were before using bundling.
fields.summary: Bundling causes automatic merge message including bundle path

fields.description:
Including Git Flow is awesome, but would it be possible to use the Git Flow AVH fork (https://github.com/petervanderdoes/gitflow)

The original Git Flow hasn't been updated in nearly a year now as where the AVH fork is constantly seeing new releases containing both fixes and features.

It functions exactly the same and should be a drop in replacement.
fields.summary: Switch to git-flow-avh

fields.description:
There are some ugly translations mistakes in the French version :
* "l'engage" for "the commit": 
you used "comitter" to translate "(to) commit", you should have kept that Frenglish form ("un commit", "5 nouveaux commits" plutôt que "5 nouvelle engage")

* "inverser" for "revert": 
the meaning of revert as far as SCM are concerned is not about inverting, it is about rolling back, "revenir en arrière" would be more appropriate.
fields.summary: Translation mistakes in French

fields.description:
I use for example the repo https://bitbucket.org/CloneVince/trackr (protected).
With 1.7.4.1 I can move a tag without any problem.

Since 1.8.x version, when I try to move a tag, I have the question "Tag Already Exists!...", I choose the button "move tag", and then I have this message : "hint: Updates were rejected because the tag already exists in the remote."

I've rollbacked on 1.7.4.1 version and it's OK again with the same repo.

Thx for your help to remove this bug.
fields.summary: Move tag doesn't work on 1.8.x - 1.9.x

fields.description:
Using Stash, a repo was copied to a different project.

In order to warn dev to start using the new repo, I tagged the original Development branch with a warning to change repo.

I updated the remote in my SourceTree repository config to use the new url.

I see new commits coming in on the new repo as expected, but the warning tag from the old repo is still showing up in my local repo.

When deleting it I get a "ref not found" error and then all is well again.
fields.summary: Tags not updating when switching to different remote

fields.description:
You add/link subtree by clicking on the SUBTREES->Add/Link Subtree. Enter details of the remote repo and local path.

Expected:
I should see the Subtree in the UI and manage the Subtree using UI.

Actual:
No Subtree is shown but files are remote subtree source code is merged into current project and available on harddisk.

Also some what related...  on the dialogue for entering Subtree details, last field "Local Relative Path:" but when you choose a path it gets absolute path. While the Submodule dialogue does this correct.
fields.summary: Sourcetree does not show Git Subtree

http://www.deltopia.com
fields.summary: Add integrated support for DeltaWalker diff/merge

fields.description:
It would be helpful to have a column in table views displaying lists of files that displays when they are modified. 

I often end up with changes across many different files that should be committed in separate commits, and the best means to select them for each commit would be by time proximity of modification.
fields.summary: Modification date column for file list table views

fields.description:
I usually use the "File status" view when I want to get the commit log or blame for a specific file, usually one that is not modified. This requires me to switch to "File status" view, then set it to show all files, then switch to tree view so that I can actually find my file. Once I'm done with it and I switch back to "Log" view, I need to set it back to show pending files in flat view.

It makes no sense to me that these two settings (file view style and filter) are shared between the "File status" and "Log" views. Those views are used in fairly different circumstances, and I find myself constantly fiddling with these options as I switch between the two views. It would be very convenient to have each view remember its settings independently.
fields.summary: Separate view style and filter for file status and log views
